caption: b'When so much changes, their dreams don\xe2\x80\x99t. Thanks to our clients, employees, and charities for helping kids like Emma, Liam and Nate rise above. #CIBCMiracleDay'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor kids with cancer, camp is one of the few opportunities that they have to connect with kids with similar experiences. At Camp Quality, we strive to improve the quality of life for children living with cancer and blood disorders through camps and year-round family support programs.

Due to the pandemic, we had to reimagine the program this year. It was essential for us to continue to connect kids to their camp community because children with cancer have experienced isolation before COVID-19 physical distancing measures were put in place.

This summer, we were able to bring the magic of camping to kids\xe2\x80\x99 homes and welcomed campers to our Camp-at-Home program. The kids were able to experience all of the fun that comes with camping and participate in a five day virtual program that allowed them to connect with other campers. We wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been able to run our virtual program without the support from CIBC Children\xe2\x80\x99s Foundation. The funding allowed us to impact the lives of 220 campers and their families.\xe2\x80\x9d

#CampQuality #CIBCMiracleDay'

b'#CIBCMiracleDay is a proud tradition that helps kids worldwide access vital support services and programs for the last 36 years. Since 1984, CIBC Miracle Day has raised over $250 million globally. This year we continue our tradition because although so much has changed, our commitment to help children and youth realize their ambitions remains stronger than ever.'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was a teenager, I ran a lawn care and landscaping business. The experience taught me that healthy financial habits are about more than making money\xe2\x80\x94they're also about making strategic investments and saving.

I was lucky to learn this lesson at a young age, but not everyone is so privileged. A few years ago, I was offered the opportunity to teach grade school classes about financial literacy with an organization called Junior Achievement Canada[PE1] (JA). JA sends volunteers into public schools to introduce students to the basics of finances. The curriculum includes engaging games and exercises that get kids excited about saving.

Given COVID-19, JA has changed its programming to be virtual. It's already a challenge getting youth excited about financial literacy in a classroom\xe2\x80\x94but it's even harder online. The effort is worth it, though. It makes me feel like I'm fulfilling my purpose. If you can make a lightbulb go off for a child who's never cared about saving or investing before, you can change their life. It's never too early or too late to learn the basics of financial literacy.\xe2\x80\x9d

-Steve T., Personal and Business Banking at CIBC"

b"My parents taught me the importance of volunteering at a young age. It's always been a huge part of my life. Even in his eighties, my dad still volunteers more than I do! Our work in the community is something we bond over. I love being able to help people, and he taught me that.

A few years ago, my dad found a local church that was collecting scarves for homeless members of our community, so I decided to make a few. Over the past three years, I've made and donated more than 150. I crocheted them by hand. I've always loved handmade gifts because they feel more personal. I hope whoever receives my scarves feels that love.

Going into the winter this year, I've been thinking about what the holidays must be like for people without homes\xe2\x80\x94and especially for homeless kids. For those without a sense of family or tradition, I wanted to donate something extra special. This year I'm making gift baskets for a local LGBTQ+ youth shelter. I'm grateful to have the opportunity to follow my purpose by supporting my community, and to have a chance to make a difference with everyday kindness.

-Melissa H., technology, infrastructure and innovation at CIBC"

b'In honour of #TransgenderDayofRemembrance, we recognize and pay respect to members of the trans and non-binary community who have lost their lives due to anti-trans violence. This year, to continue to show our support we introduced new training to promote inclusivity for trans and non-binary clients and team members, and encouraged our team members to include pronouns in their email signatures.'

b'I've always liked working with youth. I strongly believe all kids are unique, and they all have potential. We have a duty to level the playing field and set kids up for success, by extending a helping hand. 

After I started my career in financial services, I went out of my way to talk to kids about money. Growing up, no one taught me about money and investing. Providing the foundational building blocks of a financial education at an early age can be a huge opportunity to change the way kids think about life. Earlier this year, I started working with the team at The Canadian Foundation for Economic Education (CFEE). We recently launched the "My Money, My Future Challenge," a competition to develop an innovative learning resource to help improve financial literacy. We're inviting kids from across Canada to participate and help design the resource in a way that works for how they learn. The grand prize is $10,000. It's been a challenging year, and we've had to imagine the competition as a fully virtual experience. But it's so rewarding to see the vision come to life. I'm incredibly proud of what we're building with CFEE and I'm grateful that my team at CIBC has supported and encouraged me to make this dream a reality.

-Cassandra J., personal and banking business
#FLM2020 @cfee_'
b'On #RemembranceDay we remember and honour all who offer their courage and sacrifice while serving our country. #LestWeForget'

b"My husband Dr. Abbas Naqvi and I moved from Pakistan to Canada in 2012 hoping for a better life for our family. We are both dentists, and planned to carry over our careers to our new country. Our goal from day one was to be practicing dentists in Canada but first, the retraining and re-licensure needed to be completed. 

Balancing studies and family life with three young children while adapting to a new country was financially and emotionally challenging. With the support of my diversely experienced husband, I studied for nearly 3 years and finally in 2018, got licensed and started practicing. 

Every dentist dreams of being able to deliver patient care at the highest possible standard for their patients which is only possible through practice ownership, as it provides the decision making power we need. We finally achieved this goal and made the leap recently by acquiring a practice (now called Waterloo Dental) in September. It feels amazing to reach this goal. I feel truly blessed. 

Empathy was a huge part of our decision-making process when finding a bank to support the practice, and we found CIBC Business Banking to be the perfect fit. Our Advisor, Simon Belz , is totally invested in our success, and his advice on how to make the practice as profitable as possible, is invaluable. He's a true partner. 

As a result of our learning experience in the equivalency process, my husband laid the foundation of CIDE, a training facility, in late 2016 to support internationally trained dentists. I now help train these dentists, on top of running my practice. We are grateful to have the opportunity to help others find the same success that we've found. It feels incredible to help people achieve their dreams. www.cideonline.ca"

b'I've had a beard for a very long time. You could say it's "grown" to be a big part of my identity. It's also symbolic of my commitment to philanthropy. Whether I'm painting it pink for the CIBC Run for the Cure or getting different trims for Movember, my beard is a big fundraiser. 

I have personally felt the impact of cancer. I have survivors in my family, and my father passed away from cancer 10 years ago. So every year, I try to raise $10,000 for cancer-related charities. But nonprofits are having a hard time this year. I wanted to do more. I decided that if I raise $100,000, I will completely shave my face. No one has seen me without facial hair since 2006, including my wife. And thanks to the pandemic, my beard is bigger than ever. But reaching the goal would be worth it. 

I know $100,000 is a lot of money, but I believe you don't realize your full potential unless you set exceptional goals. And I'm on track. I've already hit $90,000. 
 
I'm grateful to have a team behind me that feels so passionate about supporting our community. Things may be tough right now, but if I can make things a little brighter by losing a beard, then I'm happy to shave it off. 

Greg M. works in finance at CIBC.'

b"October is #SmallBusinessMonth. In celebration of all small business we are sharing The Dutch Bakery & Diner story. Let\xe2\x80\x99s all support our local businesses when possible. The Dutch Bakery & Diner has been in the family for three generations. It's an institution in downtown Victoria. Our Grandfather Schaddelees started the business after moving here from Holland. Today, three of us cousins are joint owners and it is an honour to continue our family\xe2\x80\x99s legacy. 

We're blessed to have very loyal clients. People make the trip all the way from Vancouver and Seattle in December to stock up on treats for the holidays. We also have a strong network of regular customers in town. Support from these regulars and a quick pivot to online sales helped us make ends meet during the start of the pandemic. Our CIBC advisor, Patrick Harris, and the tellers at the local banking centre have also been incredibly supportive and flexible. 

But the pandemic was a wake-up call. We had to learn to think outside the baker's box, so to speak. We realized that an online presence is necessary\xe2\x80\x94it's what saved us at the start of all this. As we think about the future, we want to have a strong social media following. It's been pretty easy to build an online community thanks to our existing customer base. It is so special to know we have such a loyal following. Victoria is definitely a city that supports local. 

Brook, Michele, Jack @dutchbakeryvictoria"

b"October is #SmallBusinessMonth. In celebration of all small business we are sharing The Dutch Bakery & Diner story. Let\xe2\x80\x99s all support our local businesses when possible. The Dutch Bakery & Diner has been in the family for three generations. It's an institution in downtown Victoria. Our Grandfather Schaddelees started the business after moving here from Holland. Today, three of us cousins are joint owners and it is an honour to continue our family\xe2\x80\x99s legacy. 

We're blessed to have very loyal clients. People make the trip all the way from Vancouver and Seattle in December to stock up on treats for the holidays. We also have a strong network of regular customers in town. Support from these regulars and a quick pivot to online sales helped us make ends meet during the start of the pandemic. Our CIBC advisor, Patrick Harris, and the tellers at the local banking centre have also been incredibly supportive and flexible. 

But the pandemic was a wake-up call. We had to learn to think outside the baker's box, so to speak. We realized that an online presence is necessary\xe2\x80\x94it's what saved us at the start of all this. As we think about the future, we want to have a strong social media following. It's been pretty easy to build an online community thanks to our existing customer base. It is so special to know we have such a loyal following. Victoria is definitely a city that supports local. 

Brook, Michele, Jack @dutchbakeryvictoria"

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI've always been entrepreneurial. Even when I was working in the corporate world as an engineer, I felt a pull to start something of my own. I launched CanadaWheels.ca after noticing a gap in the market. Today, the company is Canada's fastest-growing online retailer of automotive wheels, tires and parts. And we're just getting started. We will continue to push the limits and grow beyond Canada to the USA and international markets. 

We've been lucky during the pandemic. Our business was well-positioned to thrive as Canadians shift to shopping online. We've stayed focused on changing buying habits, expanding our product offerings and being as transparent as possible with our clients about delays to shipping, given the pandemic. 

While growing the company and navigating the pandemic, building relationships with manufacturers here in Canada and abroad has been critical. Likewise, the relationship we've built with CIBC has been a huge part of our success. CIBC was my first and remains my only bank. I opened a student account in 2002 when I moved to Canada. Whenever I reach out to them for help, I have their full support. I'm grateful for the entire team at my local banking centre at South Keys in Ottawa." 

-Saleh Taebi, Founder & CEO, www.CanadaWheels.ca @canadawheels_ca @salehtaebi'
b'From all of us at CIBC, we wish you and your family a safe, and happy Thanksgiving.'
b'Everyday Expert, Calen McNeil @BigWheelBurger, has some useful lessons to teach you about running a small business during a pandemic. #CIBCEverydayExperts'
b'Get real home-buying advice from a real person: Manny Brar. #CIBCEverydayExperts'

b'"I am proud to say that I am a ten-year cancer survivor. A decade ago, my commitment to getting an annual mammogram allowed doctors to find a suspicious growth. It was terrifying to suddenly be faced with a disease like cancer. But early detection can make such a difference! Being able to quickly commit to a course of action saved my life. Going in for regular mammograms since then also helped us detect pre-cancerous growths and remove them before they could cause problems. I am forever grateful that I went in for that initial mammogram. I've seen the devastation late detection can cause even in my own family, and I hope my story will encourage all women to get checked, as it might save your life too"

Barbara A., Capital Markets

#CIBCRunfortheCure'

b'October is for Doug and Linda Simon, who have been participating in the #CIBCRunfortheCure since their daughter was diagnosed with breast cancer. 

CIBC plays a pivotal role in supporting breast cancer research. Since the 1990s, our partnership with the Canadian Cancer Society
(CCS) has created the largest cross-Canada, single-day, volunteer-led event in support of people affected by breast cancer \xe2\x80\x93 the CIBC Run for the Cure.

Doug and Linda, we\xe2\x80\x99re so happy to have provided you with a support system and even happier to know that your daughter is now cancer free!'

b'On #OrangeShirtDay as part of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s journey of reconciliation, we honour and remember the survivors of residential schools. We remain committed as ever to supporting our Indigenous team members, communities and clients. #EveryChildMatters'

b"CIBC is proud to strengthen our longstanding relationship with the Ronald McDonald House Charities (RMHC) as new National Mission Partner, helping to keep families with sick children close. Team member Jim shares his story. 

\xe2\x80\x9cOur CIBC team in Saskatoon has been a long-term supporter of our local Ronald McDonald House. I\xe2\x80\x99m grateful CIBC\xe2\x80\x99s new partnership with RMHC is taking that support national so more families with children going through health crises can get the help they need. 

Having been on our local board for eight years, I\xe2\x80\x99ve personally seen the difference RMHC makes by helping families focus on their kids instead of logistics like meals or accommodations near the hospital. It's especially important for families who need to travel long distances for their child to get treatment. It takes a lot out of a parent. If we can relieve part of their physical and mental burden, we're helping and showing we care.

Since COVID-19, it's been a scramble. We had to close for a while at the start of the pandemic. Luckily, we\xe2\x80\x99re back open now with new cleaning regiments and PPE. While our usual programming is on pause, at least our families have a safe, clean place to stay. We're all looking forward to when we can go back to offering everything we can to these families.

We all have a connection to children's health. You see that once you get involved. It's easy to commit to a cause you really believe in.\xe2\x80\x9d 
-	Jim F., CIBC Wood Gundy"

b"\xe2\x80\x9cOne in eight women are expected to get breast cancer during their lifetime. My wife, Ann, has four sisters. I have five. Sadly, the odds are not in our favour. 

I've been involved with #CIBC Run for the Cure for more than 20 years. Last year, I was CIBC's biggest fundraiser for the Atlantic region. I collect recyclables from friends and family to raise money for the event. It's nice to know I'm helping the environment and cancer research all at once. It also feels great to know we're doing something to change the future of breast cancer and help find a cure. 

In some ways, cancer is similar to COVID-19: it's na\xc3\xafve to assume you won't be affected. If you're not checking, you just don't know. And it's always better to be safe than sorry. I'm hopeful that our supporters will rally around this year's Run, which will be virtual.\xe2\x80\x9d 

Scott F., Commercial Banking at CIBC"
b'Staying on top of everything is what you do now. Make staying on top of your money easier with CIBC Alerts. www.cibc.com/alerts'

b'From now until September 17, 2020 at 11:59 PM PST, we will be matching dollar for dollar all donations in support of the #CIBCRunfortheCure, up to $500,000, making double the impact in the lives of Canadians affected by breast cancer! \n\nTogether, we can ensure that no Canadian has to face breast cancer alone. Visit cibcrunforthecure.com and start fundraising today.'

b"I\xe2\x80\x99m learning to be open in speaking about my disability, but it has been a journey. When I was still in university, my left eye was injured in a random accident.. After six years and seven operations, doctors told me I'd need to have the eye removed. I ended up with a prosthetic.

I struggled to process the accident and outcome, which affected me both physically and mentally. I felt isolated. In addition to the challenges caused by relying on one eye,  such as eye strain and limited peripheral vision, I also have anxiety that people might notice my prosthetic.

Finding the courage to go to therapy and being open about my condition has led to self-acceptance. I\xe2\x80\x99ve realized the more I talk about my experience, the more people are open in return. Working at CIBC, my managers and colleagues have been incredibly supportive.

This journey empowered me to support others with visual impairments, giving me a sense of purpose. I'm an advocate for the Canadian National Institution of the Blind (CNIB), and passionate about working to break down stigmas against those with visual disabilities."
b'Happy Labour Day!  Wishing you and your family a healthy and happy holiday.'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI'm officially three years cancer-free this year. To celebrate the milestone, I originally wanted to visit Sunnybrook, the hospital in Toronto where I spent six months getting treatment. I planned to bring in some surprises for the staff on the inpatient cancer ward. These doctors and nurses are the everyday heroes who supported me in beating stage IV B blood cancer.

But then COVID-19 happened, and I had to adjust my plans. Instead of visiting the center in person, I sent lunch to about 70 staff members at Sunnybrook and donated, too. I also registered for the CIBC Run for the Cure and began reaching out to my supporters.

Today, I don't take anything for granted. Little things like being able to take my dogs for a walk fill me with so much gratitude. I have my everyday heroes to thank for those moments. I try to pay it forward by bringing positive energy to others' lives. Each of us has the power to make a difference in our communities and show appreciation for those who have lifted us up.\xe2\x80\x9d - Jodi R., People, Culture and Brand"

b"We were so excited to open our first gym in 2017. Seeing clients at our F45 gym achieve their fitness goals is a never-ending source of joy. We get to watch people become stronger and more confident, which is so rewarding.

When the pandemic forced us to close in mid-March, we got to work right away trying to deliver virtual experiences to our clients. On day one, we filmed like 8 workouts. We completely reinvented the business within just 12 hours. Within a few weeks, we transitioned from pre-recorded videos to live Zoom sessions. We've seen a strong online showing, and more and more joining as the pandemic goes on.

A loan deferral from CIBC has helped take some of the pressure off,  and we signed up for Smart Banking for Business to transition to online services. Our advisor, Chad Elliott, has been in regular contact, helping us navigate government assistance programs. We got a cash infusion in July, which has really helped us sleep better knowing the business is secure\xe2\x80\x94and that we can continue helping our clients get and stay strong, even in quarantine.

We\xe2\x80\x99ve just re-opened the studio with an innovative new setup, and updated policies to keep our members safe while they work to crush their goals in-studio. It is awesome to bring our community back together in person, but we\xe2\x80\x99re still offering online Zoom classes for those that are not ready to come back just yet. And we're even taking an exciting leap of faith\xe2\x80\x94we're planning to purchase another F45 franchise. We hope to open the doors within the next year.

-Chris Grant, Leena Vadera, Owners, F45 Yonge & Eglinton"

b"Fast food isn't always associated with sustainability or community impact. But I knew a better business was possible. I started Big Wheel Burgers in 2011 with the goal of making it a carbon-neutral, community-oriented company. Within just 2 years of opening, we reached carbon neutrality. We also created the Big Wheel Community Foundation to support local organizations and nonprofits like Big Brothers Big Sisters of Canada.

When the pandemic hit, we immediately pivoted our business model. We wanted to continue to employ as many people as possible. We started offering takeout and pick-up, and we worked with local company Moduurn to launch our own app for delivery. Today, we're up to about 40 deliveries a day. We even opened a new location in Nanaimo, as well as a food truck in Courtenay. Our advisor, Patrick Harris, at CIBC helped us with financing so we could move quickly on our food truck purchase.

In order for restaurants to survive this moment, they need community support. What I\xe2\x80\x99ve found is that there\xe2\x80\x99s a real appreciation of Big Wheel\xe2\x80\x99s support of the local community as well. So we're finding new ways  to continue to give back, like opening edible gardens and urban agriculture programs. And we\xe2\x80\x99re sharing tips and ideas with other local restaurants on how to pivot. Profits take care of themselves if you focus on your community, your environment and your employees.

-Calen McNeil, Founder"

b'On August 9 we observed International Day of the World\xe2\x80\x99s Indigenous Peoples, and today are proud to share that together with our partners at Indspire and the University of Alberta, we are helping to enable Indigenous students to reach their academic ambitions through scholarships and award opportunities. Visit our story for full details. https://bit.ly/2DPC3ZQ'
b'Our new SPC+ program has launched! Open a CIBC student or youth account today for exclusive access to bigger discounts, contests and amazing experiences with SPC+. https://bit.ly/39GUOdL'
b'Lots of kids dream of being superheroes when they grow up. For Justin, It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just a dream. #CIBCMementoProject'
b'What a response, Canada! You nominated over 19,000 healthcare workers. Thank you for helping us thank our heroes. www.CIBCHolidaysforHeroes.com #HolidaysforHeroes'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe believe that helping the planet isn't about a million perfect environmentalists. It's about the impact billions of imperfect environmentalists can have working together\xe2\x80\x94big change starts small. Our company, @tentree , wants to change the world, 10 trees at a time. We plant 10 trees for every piece of sustainable apparel we sell\xe2\x80\x94our ultimate goal is to plant a billion by 2030. We've planted over 43 million to date.
COVID-19 has undoubtedly been difficult for all business owners, but online sales are continuing to help our tree-planting efforts, and we\xe2\x80\x99re in close contact with our partners at our planting sites. Planting trees has a ripple effect - it helps support the community, so we're doing all we can to ensure all of our planting sites stay open.
We couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do this without our commercial manager Justin Dickie, at CIBC. He has been a grounding force through the past few months, helping us navigate and providing resources that help us continue pursuing our vision."
Derrick Emsley, David Luba, Kalen Emsley'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI fell in love with craft cocktails and distilled spirits during a European backpacking trip. After I got a few more formal courses in wine and spirits under my belt, I realized I\xe2\x80\x99d found my passion. I love the entire production process - setting up the equipment and experimenting with the chemistry to make an amazing-tasting product. 
My business partners and I co-founded Pepprell Distilling Co. in 2016. When the pandemic started, we decided that making hand sanitizer would be a great way to do our part. 
We transitioned from producing gin to sanitizer in about three weeks. Today, we're making about 1,000 litres per week, and our goal is to eventually produce three times as much. We've been donating the product, called \xe2\x80\x9cHillwood Sanitizer\xe2\x80\x9d, to local organizations and it\xe2\x80\x99s also now available at select stores across Ontario. 
Our advisor Elaine Purdy at CIBC helped us set up digital banking solutions, and CIBC went the extra mile to enable a 300-litre donation to the Grand River Hospital Foundation to support organizations in our community. This donation was particularly meaningful to me, as it's the hospital where my son was born. 
We\xe2\x80\x99ll get back to producing spirits eventually, but right now, it\xe2\x80\x99s really rewarding to be able to get our sanitizer out to our community when they need it most.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 Josh Cormier,  Pepprell Distilling Co., Moorefield, On @Pepprelldistilling @hilwoodsanitizer

https://www.cibc.com/businessrelief"

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI had to pinch myself when we opened Lagom Studio, a pottery and interactive art studio, this past January. It was a dream come true. 
I started hosting kids' sessions on Saturday mornings and classes for adults in the evenings. I'm a former teacher, so the classes let me express my joy for teaching in a totally new way. 
But in March, the pandemic hit, so in-person classes stalled and we had to find a way to offer our students a virtual experience. We started making take-home paint-your-own-pottery kits and offering online sales. I'm a mom, so I know that quarantine has been tough on parents, and the pottery kits have been a great rainy day project. Working with pottery can also be very meditative.

With help from our advisor at CIBC, Louis Choi, we deferred the loan on our studio property for six months, which took so much pressure off and let me focus on keeping the business running. Now, we're considering how to reopen safely. I want Lagom Studio to continue to be a safe, accessible and creative space for families, both online and in the studio, and look forward to welcoming my students back soon.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 Cory-Lynn Styles, Lagom Studio, Hillsdale, On
@lagomstudiopottery 
https://www.cibc.com/businessrelief"
b'Team CIBC is still celebrating Pride with you, even when we\xe2\x80\x99re apart. We take pride in you now and always. #GlobalPride'

b'We\xe2\x80\x99re proud to support the Northern Ontario School of Medicine, ensuring that young Indigenous health care workers have access to quality training and resources in the academic medical community. Visit our story for full details. #NationalIndigenousPeoplesDay #IndigenousHistoryMonth'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re committed to working with the Black community to help drive change, including donating funds across North America. Full details in our latest news release.'

b'Even apart, we celebrate Pride together. That\xe2\x80\x99s why this month we\xe2\x80\x99ll be sharing stories of how our team members are celebrating Pride in their communities. We take pride in you.'

b'June honours the First Nations University of Canada (FNUniv), dedicated to enhancing, preserving and protecting the history, language, culture and artistic 
heritage of First Nations. CIBC has been a strong supporter, and exclusive banking partner, of FNUniv since 2007. We also looked on proudly in 2019, when FNUniv received the highly-coveted urban reserve 
status, a first for an educational institution. 
We\xe2\x80\x99re so proud to support Indigenous culture and the work that FNUniv is committed to doing.'
b'To our paramedics - thank you for all you\xe2\x80\x99re doing to protect the health of our communities. #ParamedicServicesWeek'

b'Over the next 2 years we\xe2\x80\x99ve committed $500,000 towards the CIBC Future Heroes Fund, a bursary program created as a tribute to the people who are bravely fighting Covid-19 and inspiring the healthcare heroes of tomorrow. Donate today at CIBCHolidaysForHeroes.com'

b'We\xe2\x80\x99re giving back 30 Million Aventura Points in travel vouchers to healthcare workers like Kris, a nurse who has made many sacrifices to keep others safe. Nominate your healthcare hero at www.CIBCHolidaysforHeroes.com and tag them below to let them know they deserve a break.'

b'The lives of healthcare workers like Gabriel are more stressful than ever as they work tirelessly to help others. That\xe2\x80\x99s why we created #HolidaysforHeroes to give back 30 Million Aventura Points in travel vouchers. Nominate your healthcare hero at www.CIBCHolidaysForHeroes.com and tag them below to let them know they deserve a break.'

b'Are you a student managing through the COVID-19 disruption? During these difficult times, we want to make sure you are connected to the programs and expert advice that will help you get through it. Learn more at cibc.com/studentsupport'

b'We were thrilled to be part of the annual Canadian Tulip Festival in Ottawa. This year was extra special as we helped deliver beautiful bouquets of \xe2\x80\x98Tulips of Thanks\xe2\x80\x99 to our hardworking frontline health care workers. :tulip::heart_suit:. @cdntulipfest #CdnTulipFest'

b':police_car_light: Applying for the Canada Emergency Student Benefit? Make sure you\xe2\x80\x99re registered for CIBC direct deposit with the CRA to receive your payment quicker. CESB applications open tomorrow. #CESB cibc.com/covid19'

b'Frontline healthcare workers like Christiana have given us so much. That\xe2\x80\x99s why we\xe2\x80\x99re launching #HolidaysforHeroes and giving back 30 Million Aventura Points in travel vouchers. Nominate your healthcare hero at www.CIBCHolidaysForHeroes.com and tag them below to let them know they deserve a break'
b'Extending a big thank you this #NationalNursingWeek to those working tirelessly  to support the health of our communities.'
b'Canada\xe2\x80\x99s banks are helping ease financial pressure. Together, we\xe2\x80\x99ll get through this. https://bit.ly/2Lm4HCw'
b'Thank you to our healthcare heroes for all they\xe2\x80\x99re doing in our local communities. :stethoscope::red_heart_selector: #DoctorsDay'

b'This May we honour Mohammed Anwar. Since immigrating to Canada 15 years ago, he has held several jobs, working his way up to his dream of owning a business in his new country. His own newcomer experience inspired him to start Merit Services Ltd., an employment agency dedicated to finding work for new Canadians. CIBC\xe2\x80\x99s ongoing support helped Merit Services Ltd. get off the ground, and today, it employs more than 100 people.\n\nMohammed, you\xe2\x80\x99re the embodiment of Canadian success. We\xe2\x80\x99re thrilled to be a part of making your ambitions a reality.'

b'Our thoughts are with all those touched by the senseless tragedy in Nova Scotia this past weekend. Standing united with all Canadians in offering our heartfelt condolences, we are donating $100,000 to support the @rcmpfoundation and @iwkhealthcentre and the vital services they offer. #NovaScotiaStrong'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cGrowing up, my parents encouraged me to pursue a career in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics). This path led me to a Master of Science in Geology and an MBA, taking me across the world from the Canadian Arctic as part of the Nunavik Mineral Exploration Fund, to Iran\xe2\x80\x99s Geological Survey where I served as Director, and now at CIBC where I help our business partners in Financial Crimes. 
The projects I lead are all driven by data and technology. My job requires me to be curious and open to learning new things. I love the dynamic nature and the constant innovation in our team.

But encouragement to pursue STEM careers isn\xe2\x80\x99t always the norm for women. I wish more women saw themselves in this field, and that as a society we did more to help. 
Our team here at CIBC works hard to ensure we have a gender-balanced and diverse workforce and is actively investing in the next generation through our support of organizations like Hackergal and #MoveTheDial. 
My wish for this #InternationalWomensDay is that together we continue to build and support programs that demonstrate how women can thrive across all sectors of the economy.\xe2\x80\x9d - Haddie M., Director, Toronto :camera:: @seeitbeitstemit'

b"In honour of #InternationalWomensDay, we wanted to share a story about women who are making an impact. :flexed_biceps: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we met in 2017, we realized our shared dream was to create a place where women are supported through every part of the motherhood journey.

Through our own experiences with pregnancy and postpartum, we knew firsthand about the lack of comprehensive healthcare for women in our community. There were very few places providing end-to-end healthcare services for women under one roof.

Two years later, we opened The Nest Health clinic. There's no other place like it in Vaughan. We offer support throughout the entire motherhood journey: fertility, pregnancy, postpartum and pediatrics. We have a mutual desire to empower women\xe2\x80\x94both our patients and the professionals we hire.

We couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have done this without our business banking advisor, Lisa, who understood the unique needs of female entrepreneurs and why this dream was so important to us. 
We\xe2\x80\x99ve not only built the clinic of our dreams, but we\xe2\x80\x99ve also created a place where families can thrive. From the moment women walk through our door, we want them to know they have found their community.\xe2\x80\x9d -	Dr. Daniela Arciero DC, Dr. Kinga Babicki-Farrugia ND, The Nest Integrative Health Centre, Vaughan"

b'Fred Arsenault, your wish for 100 Birthday Cards for your 100th Birthday has inspired us. We\xe2\x80\x99ve donated to the Grant a Wish Program to help the residents of The Sunnybrook Veterans Program realize theirs. We are honoured to have served you for the last 30 years.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs a leader, you have the responsibility to elevate everyone around you. That\xe2\x80\x99s because it takes everyone in the room to help move the dial.

Before becoming one of the co-chairs of the CIBC Black Employee Network (CBEN), I attended a network event that deeply impacted me. The leaders I heard from that day inspired me to want to get more involved It made me realize that when audiences feel they\xe2\x80\x99ve been impacted by what they\xe2\x80\x99ve seen or heard, they will be inspired to take action. Now I co-lead an incredible network focused on empowering professionals across the bank.

Being part of CBEN has helped me  see that in reaching and connecting with people, we also share in the responsibility to do what we can to elevate others. We become accountable to raising each other up, whether it\xe2\x80\x99s helping give them a voice at the table, or letting them know we are championing them on from the sidelines.

No matter who we are, we can inspire someone around us.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 Austin W., General Manager, Toronto\xe2\x80\x93 Austin W., General Manager, Toronto #BlackHistoryMonth'

b'February is dedicated to Marielle Thompson, Canadian freestyle skier and ski cross champion. Her ambition was to be the best in the world. She captured Olympic gold in Sochi 2014, and was crowned World Champion in 2019. While Marielle was focused on becoming a champion, CIBC stood by her with the financial support and advice she needed. Marielle, congratulations on your success. We can\xe2\x80\x99t wait to see where your ambition takes you, next.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cSix years ago, my husband was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called salivary gland carcinoma. During treatment, I was by his side for every single appointment. Having a support system during this difficult time was crucial. Thankfully, my managers at CIBC were extremely supportive, and the hospital staff at Princess Margaret Hospital in Toronto were incredible from beginning to end. 
My husband passed away two years after the diagnosis. When I decided I wanted to get involved in the 25-kilometre Weekend to Conquer Cancer fundraiser the following year, to honour his memory, I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t prepared for the surge of people from Team CIBC who came to show support. 
The beauty of The Weekend is that it lets me choose the type of research my money will support \xe2\x80\x94 mine goes toward rare cancers. But mostly, the experience helps me show my sons that even though we\xe2\x80\x99re grieving, we still need to be grateful. Seeing them get involved and learn how to turn a sad experience into a positive one is the silver lining. I work hard to stay strong and set an example for them.\xe2\x80\x9d - Preeti J, Manager Client Advice, Brampton

#WorldCancerDay'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cComing to Canada from Nigeria I noticed the banking system was drastically different, as account names and terms were different from what I knew at home. When I was getting started, connecting with colleagues was helpful in explaining these differences and helping me feel more settled. Ten years later, I am providing that same support and guidance to my team, from diverse backgrounds.

Inclusion is a big part of my team's vision \xe2\x80\x94 if you are new, no matter where you come from, we're here to help. My manager has always fostered this environment. He introduced me to the CIBC Black Employees Network, a group for black employees, providing networking and mentorship opportunities.

I've been working to bring a similar vision to Calgary \xe2\x80\x94 for all employees. The purpose is to celebrate each other, inspire people and welcome new hires.\xe2\x80\x9d -	Yemi, Financial Advisor, Calgary, Alberta."

b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur Charlottetown Islanders\xe2\x80\x94the local hockey team\xe2\x80\x94mean a lot to us. People in this city will drop everything to go to a game. When the boys went into the playoffs last year, the city was on fire\xe2\x80\x94it was a great feeling.\n\nI particularly enjoy attending games with other CIBC employees, wearing Red Jackets to represent CIBC at special events. Before game time, I like to go to the rink and chat with fans from every corner of our community to hear their story and bond over our mutual love for the sport; everyone comes together for the occasion. We\xe2\x80\x99re so fortunate to help make the experiences in our community something to remember.\xe2\x80\x9d -Glenn, Community General Manager, Charlottetown, P.E.I.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn China, lots of people move from the country into big cities for work. Lunar New Year represents an opportunity to go home and reconnect with family; it\xe2\x80\x99s a big reunion. When I left Shanghai and moved to Toronto for five years to work for CIBC, being able to celebrate such occasions was a reminder of my culture back home.\n\nAs part of the CIBC Asian Employee Network in Toronto, we celebrate Lunar New Year each year with a huge event. The bank\xe2\x80\x99s employee networks really make an effort to give people a place to celebrate their own cultures. Because so many of us are away from home\xe2\x80\x94and missing it\xe2\x80\x94during the holiday, it is great to find support through our colleagues and feel more connected to how our families are celebrating back home.\xe2\x80\x9d -Michelle, Director, Asian Banking in Hong Kong, China'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cTo invest in travel is to invest in yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d @haydenkortemoore shares why travel is so important to her, and how Aventura helps her reach her destinations faster.  #Repost
. . .
\xe2\x80\x98To invest in travel is to invest in yourself\xe2\x80\x99 :butterfly: I\xe2\x80\x99ve made a solid point over the past few years to invest a lot of my time, energy and money into seeing the world. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always thought of it as the best way to get to know myself and grow as a human being. To figure out the places that make me the happiest, the people who make me better and the activities that make me feel the most alive by putting myself in new and unfamiliar environments. But travelling, especially as a young female, can be a bit intimidating at times. I\xe2\x80\x99ve learnt over the past few years that having a solid credit card with perks that fit my lifestyle has eliminated a lot of extra stress while out on the road. It's made it easier to track my spending, it's protected me from theft and it\xe2\x80\x99s helped me enjoy my time out exploring the world just a little bit more.
\xe2\x80\xa2
I discovered the @cibc Aventura Visa Infinite Card about a year ago. The points I earned from applying for the card and using it frequently over the last 12 months helped me get down to Mexico this fall, relax, and really give surfing a go. Some of the card\xe2\x80\x99s other perks include 4 complimentary airport lounge visits per year, mobile device insurance and I even got a rebate on my Nexus Application Fee. Not to mention the \xe2\x80\x98hotel burglary insurance\xe2\x80\x99 attached to the card helped me get through a pretty tough time when I got robbed down in Costa Rica 6 months ago.
\xe2\x80\xa2
So if you enjoy seeing the world as much as I do, and are looking for a new travel card - invest in yourself by clicking the link in my bio and signing up for the CIBC Aventura Visa Infinite Card today :dizzy: Happy travels #CIBCAventura #sponsored"
